bboxes.raw_text:
SAN FRANCISCO A crowd
estimated at 5000 of Negroes
and whites marched down city
streets and expressed their dis
approval of Republican Senator
Coldwater. Signs stressed their
opposition to Barry Goldwater
and the rally ended In a meeting
in the park.


James Farmer, president of
the Congress of Racial Equality
and several others denounced the
Grand Old Party and the apparent
nomination of GoldWater.

Huge March


Against Barry

Senator Barry Goldwater, Re-
publican from Arizona, easily
overcame all opposition and re-
ceived the partys presidential
nomination We'd, July Is at the
Cow Palace.

COLBERT. Ga. Clarence Ell
lington. 48, a Negro insurance
agent of Fl. Pierce, Florida. re-
ported that he and his family were
shot at just about 24hours before
Lemuel Penn was slain.


Penn. 48, Negro. director OF
vocational high schools in Wash
ington, Dc. was killed Saturday.
when driving through the rural
district of north Georgia.


Penn, a lieutenant colonelin the
army reserve. was returning with
two companions, from duty. Gun
men in car drove past and fired
into Penn car ten miles north
east of Colbert.


The FBI and local officers are
making an intensive investiga-
tion.


Ellington case may be related
to the Penn murder.

SHOOTING MAY
TIE IN WITH


PENN'S MURDER

number of Federal representa-
tives-FBI agents. marshals and
others-to protect the safety and
lives of potential victims of the
states racism.


Also announced at the news
conference was the committees
intention to seek conference
with President Lyndon B. john
son and Attorney General Robert
F. Kennedy to report its findings
as we'll as to submit its recon-
mendations for Federal action.


DR.. H. Claude Hudson Of Los
Angeles was chairman of the
committee. Other members in
cluded DR.. Eugene T. Reed. XII
vie Kaplan, Alfred Baker Lewis.
Chester l. Lewis, l.. Joseph
Overton and John F. Davis. Ac-
companying the NAACP Board
Committee were Mrs. Alfred
Baker Lewis. representing the
Connecticut Council Of Churches
and the following staff members:
Robert l.. Carter, general coun-
sci: Gloster B. Current. direc-
tor of branches: Charles Evers.
Mississippi field secretary:and
Maurice F. White, public rela-
lions assistant.

NAACP Announces ReprisuIs
Against Mississippi

SAN FRANCISCO The hotel
room Of Edward Banks, publisher
and editor of the Arizona Tribune,
was entered and looted early
Wednesday morning.


He reported a diamond ring.
two pieces Of luggage. pair Of
shoes, a wallet containing $lOO,
a travel clock and a, gold tie
bar we're missing.


Mr.. Banks was attending the
Republican National Convention.


He estimated his total loss In
excess Of ST 200.

Tribune


Publisher Robbed
In San Francisco

NEW YORK Actor Jack Pal
ance reported that he is not as
tough as the characters he por-
trays in the movies.


Palance challenged three heck
lers In an Alabama theater to go
outside and fight one by one.


When he left the Tuscaloosa
movie last Thursday night an
angry mob was waiting. They
threatened him, his wife and
children.


He said he was frightened and
said the mob was excited about
the recent federal civil rights law
which integrated the movie
houses. They we're also inflamed
by a false story that Palance was
attending the movie with a Negro
woman.


Police were summoned and
tear gas and fire hoses were used
to repel the crowd. The car Pal
ance had rented was damaged.

Actor PuIance
FIees Mob In Alabama

MEMPHIS A five-point pro-
gram of federal intervention in
the Mississippi crisis has been
proposed by the Missippi investi-
cation committee of the NAACP.


The group recommended to the
President and the c congress of the
United States.


l. That the federal government
take over the administration of
the State of Mississippi under
provisions Of Article w, Section
4, Of the US. Constitution;


2. That the US. Commission
on Civil Rights Immediately start
hearings in Mississippi on the
breakdown of law and order and
deprivation of the basic civil
rights of Negro citizens;


8. That the Department Of Jus
tice act promptly on the many
complaints of civil rights viola
lions submitted to that Depart
ment;


4. That Federal funds be i'm
mediately withdrawn from all in
situations and agencies in Mis-
stssippi which now receive such
funds; and


S. That the government dis
patch to Mississippi sufficient

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. = Twenty
seven members of the Congress
of Racial Equality were arrested
Sunday during racial demonstra-
lions at a restaurant chain they
accused of discriminatory hir-
ing practices.


Similar demonstrations forced
two other stores in the Hayes
Bickford lunch system to close
temporarily in neighboring -Bos-
ton and Brookline.

~ JAILED
IN DEMONSTRATIONS

TUCSON = Organization of the
Tucson Committee for Constitu-
tional Rights was announced to
repeal the citys new human re-
lations ordinance.


Ken Winter, committee chair
man, said the group will begin
circulating petitions aimed at
getting the issue on the munich
pal ballot In the fall of 1868.


Winter said citizens should be
allowed a voice In the local is
sue of civil rights.


Claiming that the council die
tated to people under threats OF
violence. he said, "These places
of so-called public accommoda-
ton are owned by the residents
of this city and not by the mayor
and council"


"This new city ordinance In
trudes far beyond the national
civil wrongs act" he concluded.

Petitions Out
To Repeal Tucson
Rights Law

Willie Lee Smith, 20. 1903
w. Yuma, was shot twice in the
chest by an irate husband who said
he found him with his wife. Smith
was dead on arrival at Memorial
Hospital.


Held in city jail is Robert
Fowler, 46, 1886 E. Jackson for
investigation Of homicide.


Fowler told police he found
Smith and his wife. Bea, At,
in the bedroom at the home of
George Rankin, 1880 E. Jack
son. Fowler Said he fired u
caliber revolver four times at
Smith as he ran.

Man Killed


By Angry Spouse

WASHINGTON Two Negroes
received the 1864 Medal Of Free
dom, the highest honor of the land
bestowed by President Johnson.


Men and women who have made
outstanding contributions to edu-
cation, politics, business, jour
nalism creative and performing
arts are selected annually.


Selectees include two famous
women:

William H. Alexander. young
Atlanta cooperating attorney OF
the NAACP Legal Defense Fund
has filed the first suit under the
new Civil Rights Act. Title Two.
to compel Lester Maddox. an
Atlanta restaurant owner. to open
his place to Negroes. Maddox
had threatened Negroes with a
gun when he refused them en-
trance to his Pickrick Restaur-
ant on July 8.

On the first ballot the roll
call of | 1903 delegates gaveGold-
water a decisive 1888, Pennsyl-
vania's Gov. Scranton gained only
2l4, while others got a handful.


The entire convention roared
with acclaim for more than a
half hour when Sen. Everett
Dirksen placed G oldwater' 8 name
in nomination.


He promised a vigorous cam
paign and thanked his supporters
over nationwide television at
ll:4S pm.

CoIdwuter Wins COP


Top Spot On First Ballot

DR.. Lena Edwards. SO. physi-
clan and humanitarian. In 1868
the Chamber Of Commerce OF her
present home, Hereford, Texas,
named the Negro woman citizen
of the year.


In the arts:


Leontyne Price. 81. American
Negro concert and opera star,
first of her race to sing lead
roles at the Metropolitan Opera
House.

GEORGETOWN British Guiana
A Negro couple was shot to
death during flight from their
burning. fire-bombed house in
Perth Manaicony, 80 miles from
here. Nine other Negro houses
we're burned.


Racial clashes between Ne
groes and East Indians here have
claimed more than 90 lives in
the past five weeks.

Race Strife


Kills 5 In Cvuinu

Of the planning committee the annual summer picnic
of Wesley Methodist Church. 1902 E. Washington met Sunday
morning.


The picnic will July Is Estrella Park Avon
dale Park.


Seated from Miss Shirley Hail. Mesdames William Lit
Teton MYRTLE Whitmore, and Rollins Winsow


Standing Naomi Toer Rev. Rollins W1nslow ana Ed
ward Kuykendall.
